title: 如何參與 ICO（續）
content: 如何參與 ICO（續）Bryan YangFollowJul 27, 2018 · 4 min read順便玩玩 Etherscan前情提要：如何參與 ICO投資有賺有賠，風險請自負medium.com過了一天，我收到認證信啦！好嗨森，接下來透過連結進入官網，會顯示目前的匯率和打款的位置，這邊很好心的教我們應該設置多少的 GAS Limit 和 GWEI，並提醒我們要使用個人錢包才能收到 Token 唷．接著只要用自己錢包網該 Address 打錢就好．看到這裡就想追一下這個位置到底是做啥的．我們使用 Etherscan 來查看該位置：https://etherscan.io/address/0xd166503b4fcc75630cc66ad7ab7023336b3dd04a看到這幾天陸陸續續有人呼叫這個 Contract點擊 CodeEthereum Accounts, Address and ContractsSource Code Copy Find Similiar Contracts pragma solidity ^0.4.21; // ----------------- //begin SafeMath.sol /** *…etherscan.io可以看到這不是一份 token 的 Contract，只是用來做 Crowdsale 而已．到底是誰 Create 了這份呢？頁面的右上角有顯示 contract 的 Creator點擊後會來到另外一個 AddressEthereum Accounts, Address and ContractsThe Ethereum BlockChain Explorer, API and Analytics Platformetherscan.io這個 Address 沒做多少事，一開始收了點錢，用來付手續費，接著就 Create 了兩個合約：一個合約就是剛剛 Crowdsale，另外一個就是 Token．Token 的位置Ethereum Accounts, Address and ContractsSource Code Copy Find Similiar Contracts pragma solidity ^0.4.21; // ----------------- //begin Ownable.sol /** * @title…etherscan.ioToken 頁面PDATA (PDATA) Token TrackerThe Ethereum BlockChain Explorer, API and Analytics Platformetherscan.ioToken 頁面可以看到滿多重要資訊像是目前的 Holder 比例和交易狀況給各位有興趣的朋友做個參考．

title: Questions — ERC20
content: Questions — ERC20v vFollowMar 30 · 3 min read- (Updated) Transactions to different accounts (one fails and another one goes thru)After I deployed our contract again (with truffle), I was able to send tokens successfully (with Metamask) to one of my accounts but transactions to the other one always fail.All three accounts are under one Metamask account. The one that fails doesn’t have any ETH in it but does that matter?You can check the transactions here:https://rinkeby.etherscan.io/address/0xc7e5bd1e1b91b9f63b51934d7e6a76e778a2beb9A similar thing happens with the contract that we created yesterday. I am only able to send tokens successfully to one account only. Funnily, it’s the one that fails with the other token but works with the one we created.You can check it out here:https://rinkeby.etherscan.io/address/0x631139b4217b851a5990066dc56137fcd1b52bd0*Update: sending tokens from MEW seem to be working well for multiple addresses. Could this be a Metamask problem?-Double spendingCould you please explain again how you think is best to prevent double spending (of the token) and what kind of code do we need to include in the crowdsale (and token) contracts?- Deploying on mainnetOverall, is the process of building and deploying a contract to mainnet more or less the same as the one we did? If different, what is different?How much would it cost, roughly, to deploy a token like the one we created on mainnet?- Verifying and publishing the contract we created on EtherscanAfter our call, I copied and pasted all the files in one single txt doc which I then copied into the field on Etherscan to verify but did not work.I got an error saying it couldn’t find info about the constructor in ABI format. I didn’t know where to get that one.How can I verify when deploying from Remix?As a side note, later I deployed the same contract (the one we built) with truffle from Terminal and was able to verify it after flattening the files with truffle-flattener. So, at least I know one way of doing it :)- initialSupply — decimalsI know that when I put 10 decimals, I can send 0.0000000001 of the token.But can you please explain this below. I don’t quite get it:1000000 *(10** uint256(_decimals));How do we calculate the initial supply here?Also, the line above says we have 6 decimals (because I just put an arbitrary number there):uint8 public constant _decimals = 6;- What is the difference between our code and the one below (source)string internal _name; string internal _symbol; uint8 internal _decimals; uint256 internal _totalSupply;mapping (address => uint256) internal balances; mapping (address => mapping (address => uint256)) internal allowed;function StandardToken(string name, string symbol, uint8 decimals, uint256 totalSupply) public { _symbol = symbol; _name = name; _decimals = decimals; _totalSupply = totalSupply; balances[msg.sender] = totalSupply;I guess they’re using parts of ERC20.sol straight in the code although they’re also importing the same file.At the same time, others are saying straight away:contract TestToken is MintableToken { string public constant name = “Test Token”; string public constant symbol = “TT”; uint8 public constant decimals = 18;}I mean, the last one looks easier but which one is better if any?- Selling tokensCan you please check this code:https://github.com/bitfwdcommunity/Issue-your-own-ERC20-token/blob/master/contracts/erc20_tutorial.solA few weeks ago, I was able to successfully deploy it with Remix and verify on Etherscan but I wasn’t able to send any of it because of some “out of gas” error. Anyway, this code is supposed to incorporate a transfer ownership function, so anyone can buy tokens directly by sending ETH to the contract’s address. And supposedly the token can be listed on exchanges.Looking at the code, do you think that is the case?Related to the crowdsale, we were talking about, is there a way to incorporate such a function in the token code?- Why did we get rid of string memory in our code yesterday?- Implementing with truffle, I had to change var to const in “initial migrations” (as per instructions)Do you have any idea why that is?const Migrations = artifacts.require(“Migrations”);module.exports = function(deployer) { deployer.deploy(Migrations);};- Slightly offtopicIs there a way to link token minting to specific user actions — clucking on a link, registering on a site, spending a given amount of time or making a download/purchase?

title: How to add your GSE tokens to MyEtherWallet or MetaMask
content: How to add your GSE tokens to MyEtherWallet or MetaMaskGSENetworkFollowJun 28, 2018 · 2 min readFirstly, you can check your GSE token balance using Etherscan or Ethplorer and enter the wallet address that you have used to purchase GSE tokens with.Important: Please be cautious of incorrect/ fraudulent addresses listed under a similar or identical name.The correct token GSE, and the correct GSE address is:0xe530441f4f73bDB6DC2fA5aF7c3fC5fD551Ec838How to add GSE tokens to MyEtherWallet (MEW)Step 1: Go to https://www.myetherwallet.comStep 2: Select ‘View wallet Info’ or ‘Send ether and tokens’ and log in.MyEtherWallet: ‘View Wallet Info’Step 3. In the ‘Token Balances’ section, click on ‘Add Custom Token’Under ‘Token Balances’ section and select ‘Add Custom Token’Step 4. Enter the GSE token details below and click ‘Save’Token Contract Address: 0xe530441f4f73bDB6DC2fA5aF7c3fC5fD551Ec838Token Symbol: GSEDecimals: 4You will see your GSE token balance.Adding GSE to MetaMaskStep 1. Add and open MetaMask in your Chrome extension and loginStep 2. Select the ‘Tokens’ tabStep 3. Click on ‘Add Token’Step 4. Enter the GSE token details and click ‘Add’Token Contract Address: 0xe530441f4f73bDB6DC2fA5aF7c3fC5fD551Ec838Token Symbol: GSEDecimals: 4Your GSE tokens have been added to Metamask.Follow us on our official channels to get first-hand updates!Telegram (EN)| Telegram (CN) | Twitter | Facebook

How to issue your own token on Ethereum in less than 20 minutes.20K266Moritz NetoJORDAN PHOTO WORKSFollowSep 15, 2018 · 1 min readDude, thank you so much. It was a lot of trial and error getting this to work, but in the end, all is well… Some UPDATES for others: First of all, you don’t need the text-editor (Atom, etc). You can just paste code straight into Remix.Ethereum. You also do not need to “deploy” from MyEtherWallet and you’re better off just deploying from Remix. (This is what worked for me in the end).Also, when you are doing your verification on Etherscan, click “Yes” for optimization. I know the dude said to use “No”, but it finally worked for me when I clicked “Yes”. So… Also, not sure if it matters but the “libraries” fields will auto-populate with “0x” in all 5 fields. I went ahead and deleted all those before my successful verification.Thanks again, Mr. Neto. Between lessons from you and @IvanTheTech I’ve about got this sh*t nailed down.Such appreciation. Really. Moving on to the ICO tutorial now.

Renewing or releasing your ENS name4025Nick JohnsonDaniel KaspoFollowMar 20 · 1 min readIf you were like me and tried to do some silly things like buy “domain.eth” which ended up turning into “domain.eth.eth”, then follow the below:For step 5, you’ll want to go to this site instead of of etherscan.io (since etherscan incorrectly parses the domain and gives you an invalid hash.) https://emn178.github.io/online-tools/keccak_256.htmlIn the “Hash” box, put your domain. An example is if you owned the ENS “dresses”. Sites will refer to it as “dresses.eth” but you’ll want to just put the word “dresses” in that box. Another example, referring to my earlier mistake, if you tried to do something like “domain.eth” which is then referred to as “domain.eth.eth”, you’ll just put down “domain.eth” in that Hash box.From there you’ll copy that hash, go to the MyCrypto page, and put “0x” + the text you copied.

Sorry, I want to ask about the owner of JoyToken contract.1Jun-You LiuHsieh Yung-chenFollowApr 17, 2018 · 1 min readJOYSOwallet is a multi-signature contract. This contract should send a transaction to JOYToken contract to ask for transferring owner. A contract can only used an internal transaction (which has no txid) to communicate with another contract.You can find the transaction here: https://etherscan.io/tx/0xd5f88418f902b6514855ebb5f5781c6a9ef6dbffbf82842b5c0aeadb77af251fLuckily, there is an event log about the owner transfer in event tab.Or you can open the parity tracing tool at upper right in etherscan: (link: https://etherscan.io/vmtrace?txhash=0xd5f88418f902b6514855ebb5f5781c6a9ef6dbffbf82842b5c0aeadb77af251f&type=parity) to see the transaction detail.In the first internal transaction (the second element), you can see the sender is JOYSOWallet, receiver (to) is JOYToken, and in the input data is the command to transfer the ownership.

title: Ethereum Gas Price Trick
content: Ethereum Gas Price TrickKea TombuchaFollowApr 25, 2018 · 1 min readThe majority of Ethereum transactions use a whole number for gas price. Take a look on etherscan and click on some transactions in recent blocks to see this for yourself.There’s an opportunity to exploit this by setting the transaction gas price to X + .01 gwei instead of X gwei.If miners are sorting transactions in txpool to decide whether to include them in the next block, which they should be, then a transaction with a gas price of X + .01 gwei will be at the front of the queue for transactions using X gwei, at little additional cost.I’m surprised that no one has caught on to this yet. Any thoughts?

title: Число ежедневных транзакций в сети Ethereum превысило миллион впервые с мая 2018 года
content: Число ежедневных транзакций в сети Ethereum превысило миллион впервые с мая 2018 годаBit.Planet NewsFollowJun 30 · 1 min readПо данным сервиса Etherscan, количество ежедневных транзакций, зарегистрированных в сети Ethereum, 28 июня превысило миллион впервые с мая 2018 года.Источник: Etherscan28 июня на блокчейне Ethereum было подтверждено 1 004 170 транзакций. До этого момента в последний раз сеть ETH регистрировала более миллиона ежедневных транзакций в мае 2018 года. Рекорд был установлен 4 января 2018 — тогда их количество было равно 1 349 890.В июне стало известно, что швейцарский онлайн-банк Dukascopy разрабатывает собственный стейблкоин на основе блокчейна Ethereum.Также в июне один из программистов ETH Джастин Дрейк заявил, что нулевая фаза перехода сети Ethereum на версию 2.0 состоится 3 января 2020 года.Новости блокчейна и криптовалют в Telegram: https://teleg.run/bitplanet

title: The number of daily transactions in the Ethereum network has exceeded 1 million for the first time since May 2018
content: The number of daily transactions in the Ethereum network has exceeded 1 million for the first time since May 2018Kate CalsoFollowJul 2 · 1 min readAccording to Etherscan, on June 28, the number of daily transactions in the Ethereum network exceeded 1 million. We have not seen this for more than a year. By the way, the maximum was recorded on January 4, 2018–1,349,890 transactions.Would you like to know how many of them relate to Ethex.bet? ;)Also let us remind that the key update Ethereum 2.0 is already scheduled for January 3, 2020. This date was probably chosen for a reason, as this is the 11th anniversary of the first Genesis block of Bitcoin.By the way, we feel genuine pride that Ethex.bet is a part of large ETH community.

I just purchased a *.thisisme.eth62Jet86enslistingFollowNov 20, 2017 · 1 min readWhen you pointed it to a different address, it automatically points to that address, when anyone sends money to that name, the new address will receive it, no additional step is needed.Goto etherscan.io/enslookup, and type the name whatever.thisisme.eth and it must show you the other address as the receipient (Look for Name Info for Subdomain — Owner)If you question is about how to set “Reverse lookup” (Name tagging the wallet), that can only be done by that wallet, not by anyone else. It is an optional step, so if the other wallet is not setup in metamask, ENSListing doesn’t support setting up the name tagging yet.Please elaborate what you are trying to do, will note down the use case, and build that feature.

title: Ethereum Reaches One Million Transactions per Day
content: Ethereum Reaches One Million Transactions per DayCrypto DisruptFollowMay 8, 2018 · 2 min readEthereum has, yet again, managed to reach one million transactions per day. Data from EtherScan reveals that the first time this happened was on December 29, 2017, (during the bull run) and the last time was February 1, 2018, (when the bull run was coming to an end). This is a huge moment for the community as it shows that Ethereum is managing to gain the attention of day-traders. It may also be a sign of an imminent upwards trend in price.While on the surface, this seems like a hugely positive sign, there is also a possibility that this has happened for unsavory reasons. A cryptocurrency enthusiast on Twitter pointed out that during May 4, 2018, one Ethereum address was accounting for almost 50% of all transactions. This address was revealed to be linked to Binance, suggesting that the exchange has been handling large amounts of transactions in an inefficient manner. It is possible that this is caused by Binance’s new feature that converts ‘dust’ into BNB.Ordinarily, one address accounting for 50% of all transactions would not be too large of a problem (although it does suggest a level of centralization). Perhaps the real issue here is that Binance may not be using Ethereum gas efficiently to facilitate their transactions. Gas is the tool that allows Ethereum to run smoothly and cheaply. It is needed to process all ether transactions. If the reason why 50% of transactions were derived from Binance was due to the ‘dust’ to BNB feature, then it suggests that the company is hurting Ethereum’s ecosystem. When gas is misused it raises the prices of transactions for all users. It can also seriously slow down the blockchain.Since May 4, it appears that the amount of transactions per day has returned to a more common number, and has moved away from 1 million — suggesting that Binance has seen the error they made and have rectified it. A visit to EtherGasStation also reveals that Binance’s addresses are no longer making up nearly 50% of transactions.Originally published at cryptodisrupt.com on May 8, 2018.
